name: Thousand Island Lake
ranking_notes: THE Sierra icon - Banner Peak backdrop, countless islands
description: One of the most iconic alpine lakes in the Sierra with countless granite islands and Banner Peak as a backdrop. A bucket-list destination on the JMT/PCT. Longer approach but worth every step.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit via Agnew Meadows. Very competitive permits. Bear canister REQUIRED. Consider the High Trail route for best views.

name: Ediza Lake
ranking_notes: Classic Minarets shot, photography mecca
description: A stunning alpine lake beneath the dramatic Minarets, one of the most photographed mountain scenes in the Sierra. Access via Shadow Creek Trail from Agnew Meadows offers the most direct route.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Quota of 12 advance + 8 walk-up per day. Bear canister REQUIRED. Shuttle required to Agnew Meadows in summer.

name: Big Pine Lakes (First & Second Lake)
ranking_notes: Palisade Glacier views, Temple Crag, stunning turquoise
description: Spectacular turquoise alpine lakes fed by the Palisade Glacier - the southernmost glacier in the US. First and Second Lakes offer accessible camping with views of Temple Crag and the Palisades. Iconic Eastern Sierra destination.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. EXTREMELY competitive - one of the hardest Sierra permits to get. Bear canister REQUIRED.

name: Lamarck Lakes
ranking_notes: Vibrant turquoise, short approach, Darwin Bench gateway
description: Two stunning turquoise alpine lakes nestled below Lamarck Col, a gateway to the remote Darwin Bench. The vibrant blue-green waters contrast dramatically with the surrounding granite, making this a photographer dream destination with relatively easy access.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit via North Lake trailhead. Bear canister REQUIRED. Can be combined with cross-country route over Lamarck Col to Darwin Bench.

name: Rae Lakes
ranking_notes: Iconic loop, turquoise waters, Fin Dome views
description: One of the most stunning alpine lake chains in the Sierra, featuring crystal-clear turquoise waters surrounded by dramatic peaks including Fin Dome. A highlight of the famous Rae Lakes Loop.
permit_notes: Sequoia & Kings Canyon permit. Part of the iconic Rae Lakes Loop. Bear canister REQUIRED. Very competitive permits.

name: Lake Aloha
ranking_notes: Unique island-dotted lake, water taxi option
description: The largest lake in Desolation Wilderness, Lake Aloha is a stunning shallow lake dotted with granite islands. Accessible via Echo Lakes (with optional water taxi) or Glen Alpine. Feels like a High Sierra archipelago.
permit_notes: Desolation Wilderness permit. Water taxi available from Echo Lakes ($22/person each way, saves 2.5 miles). Bear canister REQUIRED. No campfires.

name: 20 Lakes Basin
ranking_notes: Many lakes, water taxi, highest drive-to lake
description: A stunning collection of alpine lakes near Saddlebag Lake, one of the highest drive-to lakes in California. Short approaches to multiple beautiful lakes.
permit_notes: Hoover Wilderness permit. Water taxi available across Saddlebag Lake. Bear canister REQUIRED. High altitude - acclimate first.

name: Garnet Lake
ranking_notes: Banner/Ritter views, great swimming, less crowded than TI
description: A stunning lake beneath Banner Peak and Mt. Ritter, one of the most scenic spots in the Ansel Adams Wilderness. Less crowded than nearby Thousand Island Lake.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Adjacent to Thousand Island Lake. Bear canister REQUIRED. Excellent swimming.

name: Kearsarge Lakes
ranking_notes: JMT gateway, dramatic peaks, resupply point
description: A cluster of beautiful alpine lakes accessed via Onion Valley, one of the highest trailheads in the Sierra. Gateway to the backcountry with options to continue to Charlotte Lake or connect to the JMT/PCT.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Popular as JMT resupply point. Bear canister REQUIRED. Steep but well-maintained trail.

name: Ruby Lake
ranking_notes: Stunning glacial cirque, highest trailhead access
description: A stunning glacial lake at over 11,000 feet, Ruby Lake sits in a dramatic granite cirque at the head of Little Lakes Valley. The turquoise waters surrounded by rugged peaks make this one of the most photographed destinations in the Eastern Sierra.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Starts from Mosquito Flat, the highest trailhead in the Sierra. Bear canister REQUIRED. Very competitive permits.

name: Evolution Basin
ranking_notes: Remote JMT highlight, Evolution Range grandeur
description: A spectacular high alpine basin along the John Muir Trail, featuring Evolution Lake and stunning views of the Evolution Range. One of the most beautiful stretches of the JMT.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Remote and challenging. Bear canister REQUIRED. Multi-day trip recommended.

name: Pear Lake
ranking_notes: Dramatic granite cirque, winter ski hut
description: A stunning alpine lake in the Tablelands area of Sequoia National Park, accessed from Wolverton. The dramatic granite cirque setting and deep blue water make this one of the park's most beautiful backcountry destinations.
permit_notes: Sequoia & Kings Canyon permit. Popular destination - book early. Bear canister required. Winter ski hut at Pear Lake.

name: Chickenfoot Lake
ranking_notes: Little Lakes Valley gem, easy high alpine
description: Part of the stunning Little Lakes Valley chain, Chickenfoot Lake sits at nearly 11,000 feet with minimal elevation gain from the highest trailhead in the Sierra (Mosquito Flat). Perfect for high altitude acclimatization with easy terrain.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Very competitive permits - book exactly 6 months out. Bear canister REQUIRED. Trailhead parking fills early.

name: Cottonwood Lakes
ranking_notes: 11,000 ft alpine, Golden Trout Wilderness
description: High alpine lakes at over 11,000 feet in the Golden Trout Wilderness, accessed via Horseshoe Meadow. Stunning views of the Sierra crest and excellent acclimatization for higher altitude adventures. Lake #3 offers the best camping.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. 60% quota released 6 months ahead, 40% released 2 weeks ahead at 7am PT. Bear canister REQUIRED. No campfires.

name: Hilton Lakes
ranking_notes: Less crowded chain, good fishing
description: A spectacular chain of alpine lakes tucked into a granite cirque below Mount Huntington. Less crowded than nearby destinations, Hilton Lakes offers excellent fishing, stunning mountain views, and peaceful camping in classic High Sierra terrain.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Trailhead near Rock Creek. Bear canister REQUIRED. Less competitive than nearby Bishop Pass permits.

name: Matterhorn Canyon
ranking_notes: Remote Yosemite, Matterhorn Peak views
description: A remote and spectacular canyon in northern Yosemite with stunning views of Matterhorn Peak. Less traveled than other Yosemite destinations.
permit_notes: Yosemite Wilderness permit via Twin Lakes. Remote and challenging. Bear canister REQUIRED. Multi-day trip recommended.

name: Sabrina Basin (Blue Lake)
ranking_notes: Multiple lake options, classic Bishop area
description: A stunning alpine basin with multiple lakes including Blue Lake, Donkey Lake, and Baboon Lakes. Accessed via Lake Sabrina with spectacular granite scenery.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Bishop area trailhead. Bear canister REQUIRED. Many lake options for basecamp.

name: Duck Lake
ranking_notes: Glacial cirque, Mammoth access, Purple Lake option
description: A beautiful high alpine lake accessed via Duck Pass from Coldwater Campground near Mammoth. Stunning views and excellent fishing in a glacial cirque.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Popular Mammoth Lakes trailhead. Bear canister REQUIRED. Can continue to Purple Lake.

name: Long Lake (Bishop Creek)
ranking_notes: Inconsolable Range views, lake chain
description: A gorgeous alpine lake along the Bishop Pass Trail with stunning views of the Inconsolable Range. Part of a chain of lakes including Saddlerock, Bishop, and Chocolate Lakes for excellent day hiking options.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. Popular trailhead - competitive permits. Bear canister REQUIRED. Excellent fishing.

name: Mosquito Lakes
ranking_notes: Mineral King chain, 5 lakes to explore
description: A chain of five stunning alpine lakes in the Mineral King area of Sequoia National Park. The second lake offers excellent camping with granite surroundings and clear, cold water. Classic High Sierra scenery.
permit_notes: Sequoia & Kings Canyon permit. Bear canister required. Mineral King road is winding and slow - allow extra time.

name: Virginia Lakes Basin
ranking_notes: Very easy access, fall colors
description: A stunning high alpine basin with multiple lakes surrounded by dramatic peaks. Short approach from Virginia Lakes trailhead makes this accessible while still feeling remote. Options for day hikes to Summit Lake and beyond.
permit_notes: Hoover Wilderness permit. Less crowded than Green Creek area. Bear canister REQUIRED. Beautiful fall colors in September.

name: East Lake
ranking_notes: Green Creek trail, good fishing
description: A stunning alpine lake accessed via the Green Creek Trail in the Hoover Wilderness. Dramatic mountain backdrop with excellent fishing and opportunities for day hikes to nearby West Lake and Green Lake.
permit_notes: Hoover Wilderness permit. 50% quota reservable in advance, 50% available 3 days before. Bear canister REQUIRED. Max group size 15.

name: Green Lake
ranking_notes: Easy Hoover access, good intro trip
description: A beautiful lake along the Green Creek Trail, closer to the trailhead than East Lake. Offers excellent camping, fishing, and stunning mountain views. Great option for a shorter approach or first night camp.
permit_notes: Hoover Wilderness permit. Same system as East Lake - 50% advance, 50% available 3 days before. Bear canister REQUIRED.

name: Lower Velma Lake
ranking_notes: Classic Desolation, multi-lake access
description: One of the classic Desolation Wilderness destinations with stunning granite basins and crystal-clear water. Easy access to Middle and Upper Velma Lakes for day hikes. Popular but spacious camping areas.
permit_notes: Desolation Wilderness permit. Zone quota system - book your destination zone. Bear canister REQUIRED. No campfires allowed.

name: Susie Lake, Desolation Wilderness
ranking_notes: Easy Desolation intro
description: Susie Lake is a stunning alpine lake nestled within the scenic Desolation Wilderness, known for its crystal-clear waters and breathtaking mountain views. The area offers a serene escape for backpackers, with opportunities for fishing, swimming, and exploring the surrounding granite landscapes. The trail to Susie Lake is well-maintained, making it accessible for hikers of varying skill levels.
permit_notes: A wilderness permit is required for overnight stays. Bear canisters are mandatory in this area due to wildlife activity. Quotas are in place during peak season.

name: Gilmore Lake
ranking_notes: Tallac day hike option, Tahoe views
description: A beautiful alpine lake nestled at the base of Mt. Tallac with stunning views of Lake Tahoe from the surrounding ridges. Popular but less crowded than Velma Lakes. Great base camp for day hikes.
permit_notes: Desolation Wilderness permit. Bear canister REQUIRED. No campfires. Can combine with Mt. Tallac summit day hike.

name: Heather Lake
ranking_notes: Lakes Trail chain, Sequoia classic
description: A beautiful alpine lake along the Lakes Trail in Sequoia National Park, part of a chain that includes Aster and Pear Lakes. Offers excellent camping with options to explore the Tablelands and Silliman Crest.
permit_notes: Sequoia & Kings Canyon permit. Part of the Lakes Trail chain. Bear canister required. Can be combined with Pear Lake visit.

name: Purple Lake
ranking_notes: JMT lake, great basecamp
description: A scenic alpine lake along the John Muir Trail, nestled in a beautiful cirque with excellent camping spots. Popular overnight destination from Duck Pass.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. On the JMT. Bear canister REQUIRED. Great basecamp for exploring the area.

name: Bear Lake (Emigrant)
ranking_notes: FREE permits, self-issue, no hassle
description: A picturesque alpine lake in the Emigrant Wilderness with granite domes and excellent swimming. Less traveled than other Sierra destinations, offering solitude and classic High Sierra beauty without permit hassles.
permit_notes: FREE permit - no quota system! Self-issue available 24/7 at Summit Ranger Station. One-night camping limit at Bear Lake.

name: Emigrant Lake
ranking_notes: FREE permits, no quotas, good intro
description: The namesake lake of the Emigrant Wilderness offers a relatively easy approach with classic granite Sierra scenery. Less crowded than nearby wilderness areas with excellent fishing and multiple nearby lakes for exploration.
permit_notes: FREE permit - no quota system! Can get permit by phone up to 7 days ahead or self-issue at Summit Ranger Station 24/7. One of the easiest Sierra permits.

name: Cliff Lake
ranking_notes: Dinkey Lakes, less crowded wilderness
description: A beautiful alpine lake nestled beneath dramatic granite cliffs in the Dinkey Lakes Wilderness. The area features numerous interconnected lakes perfect for day hikes from base camp. Excellent fishing and swimming.
permit_notes: Sierra National Forest permit. Bear canister recommended. Less crowded than nearby wilderness areas.

name: Lake Virginia
ranking_notes: JMT, Fish Creek hot springs nearby
description: A beautiful lake along the John Muir Trail between Purple Lake and Tully Hole. Excellent camping with mountain views and access to Fish Creek hot springs.
permit_notes: Inyo National Forest permit. On the JMT south of Purple Lake. Bear canister REQUIRED. Fish Creek hot springs nearby.

name: Bearpaw Meadow Campground
ranking_notes: High Sierra Trail, meadow camping
region: Sequoia National Park - Kings Canyon National Park
description: Bearpaw Meadow Campground is a picturesque destination nestled in the heart of the Sierra Nevada, surrounded by towering trees and stunning mountain vistas. This serene campground offers a perfect base for exploring the nearby High Sierra trails, including the iconic Rae Lakes Loop. Backpackers are drawn to its lush meadows and the tranquil sound of flowing streams, making it an ideal spot for relaxation and adventure.
permit_notes: A wilderness permit is required for overnight camping. Bear canisters are recommended due to wildlife activity. Quotas may apply during peak season.

name: Redwood Canyon
ranking_notes: Unique sequoia grove, not alpine
description: A unique grove of giant sequoias in Kings Canyon National Park. The canyon offers a peaceful escape with towering redwoods, seasonal streams, and excellent wildlife viewing. Less crowded than the main groves.
permit_notes: Sequoia & Kings Canyon permit. Bear canister required. 6-month advance booking.

name: Tamarack Lake
ranking_notes: Echo Lakes access, good swimming
description: A beautiful lake accessible via the Echo Lakes Trail, featuring classic Desolation granite scenery and excellent swimming. Good alternative to more crowded destinations.
permit_notes: Desolation Wilderness permit. Can use Echo Lakes water taxi to shorten approach. Bear canister REQUIRED. No campfires.
